awd_titl_txt: Molecular Recognition of Anionic Sulfur, Oxygen, and Nitrogen Species
awd_abstract_narration:
With the support of the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program in the NSF Division of Chemistry, Professor Michael Pluth of the University of Oregon will develop general methods to bind, differentiate, and recognize under-investigated anionic sulfur-, oxygen-, and nitrogen-containing species. These small molecules play diverse and important roles in biological systems and the environment. This research aims to gain a better fundamental understanding of how these species behave in different systems. Through conducting this interdisciplinary research, graduate and undergraduate students will receive training in organic synthesis and analytical studies in supramolecular chemistry.  In addition, the research team will engage students in local underserved middle schools in hands-on science activities to expand their exposure to STEM (science, technology, engineering and mathematics).

Professor Michael Pluth and his research team will investigate the molecular recognition of anionic reactive sulfur, oxygen and nitrogen species, such as peroxynitrite, nitrite, thionitrite, and perthionitrite. This project will focus on three specific aims. In Aim 1, synthetic anion-binding hosts will be used to elucidate the factors that influence binding of anionic guests including NO3- (nitrate), NO2- (nitrite), SNO- (thionitrite) and SSNO- (perthionitrite). In Aim 2, additional host receptors will be rationally designed and synthesized for specific recognition of SNO- and SSNO-. In Aim 3, the research team will investigate whether the anion-binding receptors can be used to modify the chemical speciation and reactivity of reactive small  molecules. Information gleaned from these investigations is expected to expand the understanding of what specific recognition motifs can be used to stabilize small molecule regulators and control the equilibria of their interconversion.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Understanding different interactions between host and guest molecules can help design receptors for specific molecules of interest. The work in this grant investigated different approaches to recognize and bind sulfur and nitrogen containing guest molecules to better understand how to engineer interactions that favor stabilization of these reactive anions. Many of these types of anions play important roles in the environment and biology. Through systematic experimentation, crystallographic analysis, and infrared spectroscopy, this work characterized new reactivity of various sulfur-based and nitrogen-based anions and provided structural and mechanistic insights into anion binding, contributing to advancements in host-guest chemistry with implications for supramolecular design, anion sensing, and reactive species control.

Specifically, this work developed host-guest system containing C-H hydrogen bond donors that showed high binding affinities and specificity for sulfur-based anions like hydrosulfide (HS-), including some of the shortest C-H---S interactions in crystal structures. In addition, this work compared the requirements of pre-organization and C-H hydrogen bond donor multiplicity across a series of anions to better understand the design principles for sulfur and nitrogen guest binding. This work also investigated other reactive anions, including hybrid sulfur-nitrogen molecules like SNO- and SSNO-, both of which are hypothesized to be important in biological crosstalk between the signaling molecules H2S and NO. Work on this project found that these anions reacted irreversibly with common recognition motifs like acidic hydrogen atoms or metals. Mechanistic investigations into these reactions revealed new fundamental chemistry including the generation of nitrosylated iron sulfur clusters from simple iron salts with SNO- or SSNO-. These results are significant because they highlight an atom economical pathway to form simple and common motifs found in biology. Further work also investigated the mechanism of the reaction of SNO- with acidic groups, which revealed new pathways for interconversion of SNO- and SSNO-, as well as pathways to form small nitrogen-based signaling molecules HNO and NO. Complementing the above studies, this work also investigated new methods of monitoring and understanding interactions between host and guest molecules using infrared spectroscopy, which allows for individual bonding interactions to be observed and dissected during the course of an experiment.

Several graduate students and postdoctoral researchers obtained interdisciplinary scientific training on this project. These research trainees learned and benefitted from training in organic synthesis, spectroscopic measurements, and mechanistic investigations. This project also helped to support STEM outreach activities that brought middle school students to the University of Oregon to participate in hands-on science activities on early-release school days.
